Innovators in Action
Surviving Dust Storms.
Ready, Set, Learn!
You need to know
• What an LDR (Light Dependent Resistor) is.
• How to write simple Arduino code and connect components (like the LDR) to an Arduino board to read data from sensors. You will be able to:
• Explore the concept of energy conservation in biology, such as hibernation or dormancy, and apply these principles to design a rover that can survive harsh conditions like dust storms on Mars.
• Understand the principles of light intensity and how it changes during Martian dust storms, affecting rover operation and energy conservation.
• Program the rover to automatically enter "storm mode" by integrating light sensors (LDR) with Arduino, enabling the rover to conserve energy during Martian dust storms.

Hey friends let’s wrap up!
How can energy conservation in biology and light intensity changes help design a Mars rover?
Energy Conservation in Biology: Animals like bears and frogs survive harsh conditions through hibernation or dormancy. These processes help them conserve energy during cold or resource-scarce periods. Similarly, engineers can apply this concept to Mars rovers, designing them to "hibernate" or reduce activity during dust storms, conserving energy for critical tasks.
Light Intensity During Dust Storms: Mars experiences frequent dust storms that reduce light intensity. This decreases the rover's ability to charge its solar panels. Engineers use this knowledge to create systems that conserve energy during low-light conditions, ensuring the rover can survive and function during extended dust storms.
